content:
I am hearing enthusiasm for Jitsi for meetings. I think this is great and love to see some experimentation with it. However, I spent a lot of time figuring out our Google Hangouts system, then figuring out our Zoom system. Right now, I think our Zoom system is working pretty good and I'm reluctant to invest my own time testing another system during regular meetings, unless we're pretty confident in the alternative or unless we have a very specific need.

My experience with online meeting software is that there are lots of unexpected places for the process to go wrong and I'm not eager to make a change unless it's for a good reason. I just have other things I would prefer to invest my time in.

If anyone else wants to schedule a meeting and figure out all the details of recording (if necessary/desired), then I am happy to join the call and help test it. But, I don't really want to have to figure out a new video conference, streaming, and recording to YouTube solution right now if I'm hosting a meeting and reponsible for making these things happen. We just got the existing system to work properly. :-)

That's just where I'm at. In a few weeks or months, I might feel differently.

I see people suggesting that Jitsi is going to be easier. If so, that is great, I'm on board. But, I'm a bit burnt out on dealing with video chat issues in the recent past and that makes me a bit skeptical that it's going to work as advertised.
From the outside it can often be hard to see how much time someone might have spent to get something working

I noticed a record meeting option that's separate to streaming to YT and which integrates with Dropbox. Perhaps someone can test that while someone else tests the streaming option. If it works, then for meetings we can have a backup either way.

This is what you see when you click "Start a Livestream".
Screen-Shot-2020-02-10-at-9.57.10-AM.jpg

Start Recording (via Dropbox) as @BWPanda (Peter) mentioned:
Screen-Shot-2020-02-10-at-9.58.39-AM.jpg

"Raise your hand" adds a little hand up icon to your video thumbnail:
Screen-Shot-2020-02-10-at-10.01.21-AM.jpg

Apparently Lullabot uses/has used Jitsi: https://www.lullabot.com/articles/using-drupal-pandemic

Using Drupal in a Pandemic | Lullabot
As we negotiate a world where COVID-19 dominates the headlines and our daily lives, considering lessons from the Drupal community might shape our understanding of these extraordinary times.
This was written my Matthew Tift, and does not reflect (sadly) what "Lullabot" does (they use Zoom heavily) but what good open source stewards should do :D He's the best

I got a bit distracted and made a new module. :sweat_smile: It's in an early stage and no formal release yet but could potentially be useful to small nonprofits or other orgs in these COVID-19 days. I'd love ideas and others to collaborate if interested. So far the basic implementation allows you to create a field of the "Jitsi Meet" type, and then it embeds a video conference through Jitsi Meet on that page (or term, or user profile... etc.) There are some settings that would make sense to expose on a module basis, as well as on a per-instance basis as future improvements.

https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/jitsi

backdrop-contrib/jitsi
Easily add Jitsi Meet video conferences to Backdrop CMS. - backdrop-contrib/jitsi

I'm going to add a setting to this module so people can enter a custom domain (in case they've installed Jitsi on their own server). I'm trying to decide if this module would fit best under Configuration > Media or Configuration > Web services -- anybody have a suggestion?
I kinda think of 'web services' as third-party stuff.
